abstract.text: Create a browser that renders content using an alternative browser engine.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A web browser loads content and code from remote — and potentially untrusted — servers.
Design your browser app to isolate access to operating system resources, the data of the person using the app, and untrusted data from the web.
Code defensively to reduce the risk posed by vulnerabilities in your browser code.
If you use
to render web content in your browser app, WebKit automatically distributes its work to extensions that isolate their access to important resources and data.
Whether you use
or write your own alternative browser engine, you need to request the entitlement to act as a person’s default web browser.
For more information, see
If you use an alternative browser engine in your app, you must design your secure browser infrastructure to separate different components into extensions that your browser manages.
Design a limited inter-process communication (IPC) protocol that coordinates work across the extensions.
Separating your alternative browser engine into distinct extensions limits the impact of security vulnerabilities in any one process.
For more information on designing your browser extensions, see
For information on using the extensions in your browser, see

Your browser app can get significant benefits by integrating closely with UIKit. You can customize the way your app handles many low-level user interface events, ensure that your browser app correctly renders CSS, and that it properly manipulates the Javascript DOM.
You can use view classes in
to handle scrolling, drag interactions, and the context menu in your browser app.
For information on integrating a custom text view with the UIKit text system, see
In your browser app, launch extensions as the person browses web content to make network requests, load the web content, and render media.
For more information, see
Use
to communicate between your browser app and extension processes.
For more information, see
For information on installing alternative app marketplaces from their company websites within your browser app, see
To distribute an app that uses an alternative browser engine, you need to request the relevant entitlements for your developer account.
For more information and to request the entitlements, see

when the context menu gestures are first recognized and a possible menu presentation is not immediately known.

subclass with features specific to browsers to enable asynchronous preparations and behaviours.
A protocol to which the drag interaction delegates conform.
A scroll view that works with its delegate to handle nesting, and customize scroll interactions.
The protocol that browser scroll view delegates conform to.
An object that represents a change in a scroll view’s scroll state.
An object that represents a web app manifest.
